IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDesc: Use the power of law to secure dignity, opportunity & well-being for people w/illness & disability.
IRS990.MissionDesc: Legal Council for Health Justice uses the power of law to secure dignity, opportunity, and well-being for people living with illness or disability. All programs combine direct service, public policy, and education/outreach.
IRS990.Desc: Children & Families Program: This program provided legal services to children with complex health conditions in medical-legal partnerships with ACCESS Community Health, Comer Children's Hospital, Lurie Children's Hospital, and Mt. Sinai Hospital.

ProgSrvcAccomActy2Grp.Desc: HIV Program: This program, continuing work started 32 years ago at the height of the AIDS crisis, provided legal services to people living with or impacted by HIV and other chronic health conditions. The project has medical-legal partnerships with Christian Community Health Center, the Core Center of Cook County Health and Hospitals System, Howard Brown Health, the Michael Reese HIV Project at UIC, and TPAN.

ProgSrvcAccomActy3Grp.Desc: Homeless Program: This program focused its legal advocacy on people who have serious mental or other health issues and are homeless. Working with social services agencies across Chicago including the AFC Center for Housing & Health, All Chicago SOAR Program, Franciscan Outreach, Matthew House, Safer Foundation, and Urban Breakthrough Ministries, program staff have worked with clients to help them gain access to disability income, health care, substance abuse treatment, and other benefits that empower clients to stabilize their lives and sustain housing.

SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: FIN 48 Note from Audited Financial Statement The Organization was granted an exemption from federal income taxes by the Internal Revenue Service pursuant to the provisions of Internal Revenue Code Section 501(c)(3). The Organization qualifies for the charitable contribution deduction under Section 170(b)(1)(A)(vi) and has been classified as an organization that is not a private foundation under Section 509(a)(1). The tax-exempt purpose of the Organization and the nature in which it operates is described above. Management's assertion is that there are no uncertain tax positions and the Organization continues to operate in compliance with its tax-exempt purpose. The Organization's annual informational and income tax returns filed with the federal and state governments are subject to examination generally three years after they are filed.
Grant agreement is in place, grants are paid for work to be done under the grant agreement.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, line 4
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Bylaws have been updated with revisions to the whistleblower policy, confidentiality policy, policy barring political contributions, Executive Director Compensation and operating budget policy.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 11b
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Form 990 was provided to the entire Board prior to filing. The Form 990 was also reviewed by the Finance Committee of the Board of Directors prior to filing.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 12c
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: An assessment of conflicts of interest is done annually and as potential conflicts arise.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, line 15
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: Compensation is determined using comparability data and is reviewed and approved by the Board of Directors.

SupplementalInformationDetail.FormAndLineReferenceDesc: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, line 19
SupplementalInformationDetail.ExplanationTxt: The Organization makes its governing documents, conflict of interest policy and financial statements available upon request.
The process has not changed from the prior year.
